summary: This is a defense filing by Ghislaine Maxwell's attorneys to Judge Alison J. Nathan, responding to the government's October 7, 2020 letter. It accuses the government of failing to meet discovery deadlines, producing irrelevant or unreadable materials, and withholding exculpatory evidence, thereby prejudicing Maxwell's ability to prepare her defense. The filing also details logistical problems with Maxwell reviewing discovery while detained at the MDC.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case. Her defense attorneys argue the government has failed to provide adequate discovery, impairing her ability to defend herself against charges related to Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case. The letter is addressed to her, requesting court intervention regarding discovery issues and detention conditions.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referenced as the central figure in the prior Florida investigation and the Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA). The defense argues much of the discovery relates to him and not the charged time period.

persons.name: Jeff S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman who signed the filing. His contact information is listed at the top of the letter.

connections.description: The indictment alleges Maxwell conspired with Epstein. The defense argues discovery materials relating to Epstein are not relevant to the specific charges against Maxwell.
Pagliuca is one of Maxwell's defense attorneys, filing this letter on her behalf and detailing efforts to secure proper discovery for her.
Maxwell is the defendant in the case over which Judge Nathan is presiding. The defense is petitioning the judge for relief regarding discovery and detention conditions.

events.title: Initial Conference / Detention Hearing
events.description: The government promised to review and produce prior investigative files from the Southern District of Florida, characterizing them as part of the 'core of the case.'

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA)
events.description: The government entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein. The defense states the government has not provided information about its genesis, which will form the basis of defense motions.

events.title: Government's Letter to Court
events.description: The government sent a letter to the court regarding its discovery plan, which the defense characterizes as abandoning agreed deadlines and redefining obligations.

events.title: Charged Conspiracy Period
events.description: The indictment alleges crimes occurred during this three-year period. The defense argues the discovery lacks specifics about dates and locations within this timeframe.

keyFacts: The defense alleges the government has failed to produce the 'core' discovery from the Florida Epstein investigation as promised, instead providing largely irrelevant materials from the 2000s.
The defense claims the indictment is deficient because it lacks specific dates, locations, and the identity of accusers for the alleged crimes occurring between 1994-1997.

The defense argues the government is withholding exculpatory evidence, including information that dozens of women accusing Epstein did not implicate Maxwell, and details about meetings between accusers' lawyers and the government in 2016.

Ghislaine Maxwell faces significant obstacles reviewing discovery while detained at the MDC, including receiving late, unreadable files and being restricted in how she can interact with her attorneys during visits.
The defense implies the government's proposed timeline for witness disclosures (4-8 weeks before trial) is inadequate for a case with decades-old, international allegations.
